interpolate

public final void interpolate(float[] from,
                              float[] to,
                              int componentCount,
                              float timeRatio,
                              float[] output)
Description copied from interface: Interpolator
Calculate an interpolated value.

An interpolator calculates an interpolated value in its own way. The initial value (from[]), the final value (to[]) and a time ratio are involved in the calculation.

The range of time ratio is from 0.0 to 1.0. The time ratio 0.0 means the start point of a given timespan and the time ratio 1.0 means the end point of a given timespan. If 0.0 is given, the same value as from[] will be copied to output[]. Likewise, if 1.0 is given, the same value as to[] will be copied to output[]. In other cases, each Interpolator implementation performs calculation in its own way.

For example, an Interpolator implementation that does linear interpolation will generate [3.0] based on the equation shown below when [2.0], [6.0] and 0.25 are given as from[], to[] and timeRatio. 

 output[i] = (from[i] * (1.0 - timeRatio)) + (to[i] * timeRatio)

Specified by:
interpolate in interface Interpolator
Parameters:
from - The value at the start point of a given timespan. The length of the array must be equal to or greater than componentCount.
to - The value at the end point of a given timespan. The length of the array must be equal to or greater than componentCount.
componentCount - The component count of from[] and to[]. The value must be equal to or greater than 1.
timeRatio - A time ratio. It must be in between 0.0 and 1.0.
output - A place into which the calculated value is put. The length of the array must be equal to or greater than componentCount.

                                      float[] to,
                                      int componentCount,
                                      float timeRatio,
                                      float[] output)
